name: cement production, CP III | cement, CP III | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19894/documentation

The dataset describes the production of Portland blast-furnace slag cement in Brazil. Portland blast-furnace slag cement in Brazil (CP III) has between 35% to 70% of blast-furnace slag in mass composition.;Granulated blast furnace slag is a byproduct of iron production and, when finely ground, it is also a cementing material with hydraulic properties. Slag hydration alone is too slow to give structural properties to cement, but when the slag is combined with Portland cement, the hydration is accelerated due to the extra amount of calcium hydroxide and gypsum. The blast furnace slag is granulated in the iron industry, but usually ground in the cement plant. This extra energy for grinding may be important; however, it is not evaluated due to the lack of specific data of energy consumption per type of cement (electricity consumption in cement plants are informed as a whole).;Six types of Portland and blended cement types represent Brazilian production. The table below presents the different cement types and compositions according to Brazilian standards (NBR 11578:1991, NBR 5735:1991, NBR 5736:1991, NBR 5733:1991).;The CP III cement type represents 14.2% of the market according to the National Union of the Cement Industry (SNIC, 2013). This cement is produced in regions next to iron industrial areas using its byproduct blast-furnace slag. CP III applications range from reinforced and ordinary concrete to coating mortars. The blast furnace slag in cement gives properties to concrete such as lower hydration heat and protection against sulfate and chloride attack. The CP III cement consists of clinker, calcium sulfate, milled limestone, and 35-70% blast furnace slag (see composition in the table).;This dataset contains information from clinker stockpile to cement ready to be shipped in bulk. After the clinker is cooled from the rotary kiln, it is ground in ball or roller mills to particles under 75 μm size. Then it goes to silos where it is mixed with calcium sulphate (gypsum) and SCMs. The mixed cement goes to a finishing mill and then it is stored in cement silos, ready to be shipped in bulk or packed.;Primary data were gathered from six cement manufacturers in Brazil, who informed the total values of inputs and outputs related to cement production in 2016, considering all their cement production sites. All types of flows were reported, namely: primary and secondary raw materials and fuels, auxiliary materials, electricity and water consumption. It corresponds to 70% market share, considered a good representativeness level. Although particulate emissions may occur, they are not reported due to lack of specific data for the cement grinding step (air emissions are monitored for the integrated clinker-cement plant as a whole and reported in the clinker production process).

The activity starts with the reception of raw materials in the cement plant. In plants which are integrated with clinker production, clinker is stored in the silo after cooling in the upstream process (clinker production /BR).

The activity includes the drying of raw materials, the grinding and mixing of raw materials for cement production in the cement mill (with grinding aids) and ends with cement stored in silos, ready to be shipped. Waste or particulate emission are not considered due to the lack of data. The dataset does not include packaging and administration.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2394:Manufacture of cement, lime and plaster

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Time period corresponds to data collection period (2016).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents production of Portland cement with blast-furnace slag 35-70% for Brazil.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Current technology for cement production in Brazil.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data represent 70% of Brazilian cement production. This sample is extrapolated to represent the production in the whole country. The main values are considered representative for a typical production of Portland blast-furnace slag cement in Brazil.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data represent circa 70% of the Brazilian cement production in 2016, which is considered a good representativeness level. Data were provided by six cement manufacturers, via confidential questionnaires, regarding the production of cement during the year of 2016. Raw materials flows are the weighted average of the cement composition informed by each cement manufacturer. The weighing factor used is the total cement production volume, since manufacturers did not report the production volumes of each cement type due to confidentiality. Basic uncertainty was calculated based on the sample"s weighted standard deviation and represents variation of composition between manufacturers/factories. For other input flows (grinding aids, materials for equipment maintenance, fuels, electricity, water consumption), the weighted average of each manufacturer"s unit flows was calculated. Except for the grinding aids, all other flows are not distinguished by cement type, as their consumption is reported for the whole cement plant, which usually produces more than one cement type. Water consumption was usually reported for the whole integrated cement plants (clinker + cement production operations). Based on literature and expert opinion, the total water volume was divided equally between the clinker and the cement production processes and then converted into unit flows. Raw materials and fuel inputs were considered to be dry. As water is mainly used for cooling and dust control, it was considered that all water evaporates, except for the "tap water" input, which was considered to be used as drinking water and whose output is modelled as an effluent. Fuel consumption was informed by manufacturers in terms of volume or mass. They were converted into energy using their lower heating values and modelled as a heat input, to simplify the dataset and allow the consideration of corresponding air emissions. Infrastructure input flow (cement factory) was extrapolated from "cement Portland/CH" dataset (accessed 08.10.2017). The amounts of the exchanges were calculated considering the weighted average of the sample. No conversion to the geometric mean of the lognormal distribution was done, for consistency reasons with other ecoinvent datasets.

exchanges.description: Cement’s bulk density ranges from 2,8 g/cm³ to 3,2 g/cm³.

Raw material for cement production.In Brazil, around 70% of the blast furnace slag used in cement making is ground along with clinker in the cement plant, not in the steel making plant. The energy for grinding is declared in the cement dataset (average aggregate data for all cement types).
